entry.title: Combined summary - PAPER: New algorithm for the discrete logarithm problem on elliptic curves
entry.summary: On April 7, 2015, Jean-Paul Kogelman sent a communication that contained a link to a research paper posted on eprint.iacr.org discussing a new algorithm proposed for the Discrete Logarithm Problem (DLP). The DLP is an essential component of many cryptographic systems, including Bitcoin. The link was shared on Reddit in a post titled "New Algorithm for the Discrete Logarithm Problem," where users discussed the potential implications of this algorithm for Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies. While the paper itself does not mention Bitcoin or any specific cryptographic system, the potential impact of this new algorithm on the security of such systems is a cause for concern.In addition to this, there is also a brief context message from someone named 'jp', which includes a link to a PDF document hosted on the International Association for Cryptologic Research (IACR) ePrint archive. The document was published in 2015 and has the file name '310.pdf'. Upon clicking the link, the PDF document opens and appears to be a research paper titled "Efficient Zero-Knowledge Contingent Payments in Cryptocurrencies with Applications to Bitcoin", describing a method for creating efficient zero-knowledge contingent payments using cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin. The authors explain how their method can be used to create smart contracts that only execute under certain conditions, without revealing any additional information about the parties involved.Furthermore, on the same day, Jean-Paul Kogelman sent an email stating that it was a false alarm and apologized for spamming. Prior to this, Gregory Maxwell had shared a link about a new algorithm for the discrete logarithm problem in Bitcoin-related discussion on Reddit. However, the situation turned out to be "easy" and no further information was given regarding the false alarm. An email signature promoting BPM Camp, a free virtual workshop to learn process modeling best practices with Bonita BPM through live exercises, was included at the end of the email thread. The email was sent to the Bitcoin-development mailing list hosted by SourceForge.Overall, while the context provided is brief and lacking in detail, the linked papers and email threads provide a fascinating look into the world of cryptography and the potential uses of smart contracts in cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin.
